title: Education support services for improving school engagement and academic performance of children and adolescents with a chronic health condition
authors: Barnett, T; Tollit, M; Ratnapalan, S; Sawyer, SM; Kelaher, M

response.output:
Plain Language Summary Title
Can education support services help children and teenagers with long-term health conditions at school?

Key Messages
– We are very uncertain if education support services help children and teenagers with long-term health conditions (illnesses that last for a long time) to stay engaged with school or do better in their schoolwork.
– Education support may slightly improve a child's mental health, for example, by improving their self-esteem.
– There is very little research on this topic, so we need more and better studies to be sure about the effects of these services.

What is a long-term health condition in children and teenagers?
A long-term (or chronic) health condition is an illness that lasts for a long time. It usually cannot be cured completely and does not go away on its own.

Having a long-term health condition can mean a child or teenager misses a lot of school. This can make it hard for them to keep up with their learning and stay connected with friends. When children miss school, it can affect their grades, their well-being, and their future career choices.

Education support services are designed to help children with long-term health conditions stay connected to their school and their learning, especially when they have to be away due to their illness.

What did we want to find out?
We wanted to find out if education support services help children and teenagers (aged 4 to 18) with long-term health conditions.

We were interested in how these services affected:
– staying engaged with school
– doing better in schoolwork
– mental health and well-being
– returning to school more easily after being away

We also wanted to know if there were any unwanted effects from these services.

What did we do?
We searched for studies that looked at education support services for children and teenagers with long-term health conditions. We compared and summarized the results of the studies and rated our confidence in the evidence, based on factors such as how the studies were done and how many people were in them.

What did we find?
We found 4 studies with a total of 359 children and teenagers. Three studies focused on children with cancer, and one study focused on children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), a condition that affects concentration and behavior.

School engagement
The results suggested that education support might help children stay engaged with school.

Schoolwork
The results for schoolwork were mixed. One study suggested it helped, while another suggested it did not. Because of this, we do not know if these services improve schoolwork.

Mental health
There was some evidence that education support may slightly improve children's mental health, such as their self-esteem.

Returning to school
We are uncertain if these services help children return to school more easily after being away for their health.

Unwanted effects
None of the studies looked at the children's overall quality of life or any unwanted effects of the support services.

What are the limitations of the evidence?
We have very little confidence in the results.

This is because we found only a few small studies. There were also some problems with how the studies were done, which could make the results less reliable.

Because the studies only included children with cancer or ADHD, we do not know if the results would be the same for children with other long-term health conditions.

How up to date is this evidence?
The evidence is up to date to January 2021.
